lexUnit.name: struggle.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to fight against an enemy or some kind of feature, esp. when the odds of victory are slim

sentence.text: Wilkins began struggling with a constable and pushed him into a bush .
Schoolboy James was hit in the mouth as he struggled with the raiders .
He has had to struggle with nature ; compete with the most brilliant men and women of his generation ; labour to outstrip his own achievements .
Many a parent struggling with an unruly child may be surprised to hear this , but as the developmental psychologist Mary Ainsworth observes :
Even now , as Congress struggles with the legislation to meet this year 's deadline , it is clear that another target will not be met .
For several days we struggled with the wind and waves , but at last the storm died away and the sea was calm again .
They have everything to gain by struggling against rivals in other wolf bodies ( although the fact that a wolf-pack is likely to be a kin group will mitigate the struggle ) .
It was terribly important that I should beat him , and I struggled desperately against the invisible forces that always prevent one running in dreams .
Manager Alan Lockwood was forced to bring in a number of young faces and he could only look on agonisingly as they struggled against more experienced golfers in gusting winds .
Andy Payton wasted the penalty , saved by Shilton , and Middlesbrough once again struggled against ten men .
The owners of smaller industrial enterprises usually retained many of the antiaristocratic views of the early nineteenth century , when the bourgeoisie had been struggling against the Old Regime .
Thus was the criminal equated with the Vietcong soldier , the only difference being that the former was struggling against capitalism on the home front .
Daniel struggled but was no match for the two louts who , having kicked and beaten him , pushed him down a grassy bank towards the canal .
I have been struggling with my marriage for years largely because of my mood swings .
Since we can not go on struggling with one another indefinitely , Hegel says that one must submit to the other .
In that sense , she died a failure ; but she died with the respect , even admiration , not just of her supporters , but of those Protestant lords who had struggled against her .
Just as they have struggled against West Indian speed , they have now been unhinged by Indian spin .
Communists and Social Democrats are struggling in Hungary , where a two-round parliamentary election starts on March 25th .
Many welfare lobbyists and pressure groups are still struggling with the legacy of the Thatcher years , especially the Fowler reviews and the 1986 Social Security Act changes .
Earlier this week police struggled with thousands of workers who attempted to enter the parliament to shouts of ` give us bread " .
